title: 106_s1346
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Office of Advocacy Act". Congress acknowledges the burden of excessive regulations on small businesses and the reluctance of Federal agencies to comply with regulatory requirements. The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration is recognized as an effective advocate for small businesses, needing independence and sufficient resources to fulfill its role. The Office of Advocacy needs independence to advocate for small businesses effectively, with sufficient resources for research on regulations' impact. Its expertise makes it a valuable adviser to Congress and executive branch agencies. The purposes of this Act are to ensure the Office of Advocacy's independence and financial resources to advocate for small businesses, report to Congress and the President on regulatory compliance, and enhance its role under chapter 6 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. OFFICE OF ADVOCACY. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section, SEC. 32, for the Office of Advocacy. The Office of Advocacy, established under SEC. 32 of the Small Business Act, includes the Chief Counsel appointed by the President from civilian life, without political affiliation, to manage the Office. The Chief Counsel cannot serve as an officer or employee of the Small Business Administration for five years. The Office of Advocacy, established under SEC. 32 of the Small Business Act, includes the Chief Counsel appointed by the President from civilian life, without political affiliation, to manage the Office. The Chief Counsel may not serve as an officer or employee of the Small Business Administration for five years. The Chief Counsel can be removed from office by the President with notification to Congress. Each appropriation request submitted by the Administration must include a separate request for the Office. The Office's primary functions include examining the role of small businesses in the US economy and their contribution to competition, economic and social mobility, inflation control, production, and employment opportunities. The curr_chunk discusses the importance of small businesses in improving competition, economic and social mobility, inflation control, production, employment opportunities, productivity, exports, innovation, and entrepreneurship. It also mentions assessing Federal subsidy programs, reducing emphasis on them, evaluating government regulation impact, and examining the tax structure on small businesses. The curr_chunk focuses on proposals to reduce excessive regulation on small businesses, alter the tax structure to benefit small businesses, address credit needs, recommend financial assistance methods for minority and women-owned enterprises, and improve business education and training. The curr_chunk focuses on evaluating efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, making recommendations to strengthen small businesses, and creating an environment for all businesses to compete effectively and expand. It also discusses the desirability of developing rational criteria to define small businesses. The Office evaluates efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, determines common reasons for small business successes and failures, and recommends corrective actions to improve small business regulations. It also considers developing rational criteria to define small businesses and serves as a focal point for receiving complaints and suggestions regarding small business policies. The Office evaluates and recommends improvements for small business regulations, represents small businesses before federal agencies, and collaborates with public and private entities to disseminate information on government programs for small businesses. The Chief Counsel of the Office can appoint additional personnel without following civil service laws to help with duties. Compensation for appointed personnel can be determined without adhering to certain provisions of the United States Code. The Chief Counsel of the Office can appoint personnel without following civil service laws for compensation, not exceeding GS-15 rates. The Chief Counsel may also procure temporary services and consult with experts in relevant fields. The Chief Counsel of the Office can consult with experts in various fields, use advisory councils, appoint advisory boards, and hold hearings as needed. The Chief Counsel of the Office may hold hearings, secure information from federal agencies, and submit annual reports to the President and Committees. The Administrator provides necessary office space, equipment, and supplies for the Office's operation. The Chief Counsel of the Office can request information from federal agencies and submit annual reports to the President and Committees on Small Business. Additionally, the Chief Counsel may prepare and publish additional reports as deemed appropriate. No report can be submitted to the Office of Management and Budget or any other federal department before being submitted to the President. The Chief Counsel of the Office can request information from federal agencies, submit annual reports to the President and Committees on Small Business, and prepare additional reports as needed. No report can be sent to the Office of Management and Budget or any other federal department before being submitted to the President and Congress. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Office to carry out its duties. Title II of Public Law 94-305 is repealed, and the Incumbent Chief Counsel for Advocacy will continue to serve in their position. The Senate passed the document on November 5, 1999, attested by Gary Sisco, Secretary.
